content.title: Status Epilepticus
content.summary: Status epilepticus (SE) is a life-threatening neurological emergency defined as a seizure lasting >5 minutes or multiple seizures without recovery between. It requires immediate treatment with benzodiazepines followed by second-line agents and consideration of anesthetic agents for refractory cases.
key_points: Definition: Seizure >5 min OR â‰¥2 seizures without return to baseline (operational)
Traditional definition: >30 min; neuronal injury begins at 30-60 min
First-line: IV lorazepam 4mg or IM midazolam 10mg (if no IV access)
Second-line: IV fosphenytoin, levetiracetam, or valproate
Refractory SE: Continuous seizures despite two AEDs; requires anesthetic infusion
Mortality 20-30% in adults; higher with prolonged duration and older age
content.statement: Status epilepticus is a seizure lasting beyond 5 minutes requiring emergent benzodiazepine treatment, second-line antiepileptic drugs, and consideration of anesthetic agents for refractory cases to prevent permanent neurological injury.

explanation.intuition: Think of status epilepticus as a brain 'electrical fire' that, unlike normal seizures, doesn't self-extinguish. The longer it burns, the more permanent damage occurs. First responders use benzodiazepines as a 'fire extinguisher,' but if that doesn't work, progressively stronger agents are needed to stop the fire before irreversible brain injury occurs.
explanation.key_insight: TIME IS BRAIN in status epilepticus. The 5-minute operational definition exists because benzodiazepines become less effective as seizures continue (GABA receptor internalization), and neuronal injury accelerates after 30 minutes. The treatment protocol should be memorized and executed rapidly.
explanation.technical_details: With prolonged seizures, GABA-A receptors internalize, reducing benzodiazepine efficacy. NMDA receptors move to the surface, increasing excitotoxicity. Systemic complications include hyperthermia, rhabdomyolysis, acidosis, pulmonary edema. EEG monitoring is essential to detect non-convulsive SE and confirm seizure termination.

definitions_glossary.status_epilepticus: Seizure lasting >5 minutes or repeated seizures without recovery between
definitions_glossary.convulsive_SE: Generalized tonic-clonic seizure activity lasting >5 minutes
definitions_glossary.non_convulsive_SE: Subtle or electrographic seizures without convulsions; altered consciousness
definitions_glossary.refractory_SE: Seizures continuing after adequate doses of first and second-line agents
definitions_glossary.super_refractory_SE: Seizures continuing >24 hours after anesthetic initiation including recurrence
definitions_glossary.benzodiazepine: First-line agents (lorazepam, midazolam, diazepam) enhancing GABA-A inhibition
definitions_glossary.fosphenytoin: Prodrug of phenytoin; sodium channel blocker; second-line agent
definitions_glossary.burst_suppression: EEG pattern goal for anesthetic treatment of refractory SE
definitions_glossary.GABA_A_receptor: Inhibitory receptor targeted by benzodiazepines; internalizes with prolonged seizures
definitions_glossary.NMDA_receptor: Excitatory glutamate receptor; upregulates during prolonged seizures
definitions_glossary.postictal_state: Period of confusion/lethargy after seizure resolution
definitions_glossary.Todd_paralysis: Transient focal weakness after focal seizure

pathophysiology.mechanism: Prolonged seizures cause GABA-A receptor internalization (reducing inhibition) and NMDA receptor upregulation (increasing excitation), creating a self-perpetuating loop and excitotoxic neuronal injury

phases.early: 0-30 min: Compensated; BP/glucose elevated; benzodiazepines effective
phases.late: 30-60 min: Decompensation begins; hyperthermia, acidosis, hypotension
phases.prolonged: >60 min: Irreversible neuronal injury; multi-organ failure

etiologies.febrile_SE: Children with febrile SE (most benign prognosis)

clinical_recognition: Repeated seizures without return to baseline consciousness
Subtle SE: minimal motor activity but altered consciousness with EEG seizures

imaging: CT head to rule out structural cause (after stabilization)
EEG: Continuous monitoring to detect non-convulsive seizures and confirm termination

medications.dose: 10mg IM (if no IV) or 0.2 mg/kg IN
20 mg PE/kg IV at 150 mg PE/min

refractory_SE.goal: Burst suppression on EEG for 24-48 hours

definition.@value: A neurological emergency defined as a seizure lasting more than 5 minutes or repeated seizures without recovery, requiring urgent treatment to prevent permanent brain injury

scopeNote.@value: Covers definition, pathophysiology, and stepwise treatment of status epilepticus

learning_objectives: Define status epilepticus using operational (5 min) and traditional (30 min) criteria
Execute stepwise treatment protocol: first-line, second-line, refractory
Explain pathophysiology of benzodiazepine resistance with prolonged seizures
Recognize non-convulsive status epilepticus and need for EEG
Identify indications for continuous EEG monitoring and anesthetic infusions
clinical_pearls: Benzodiazepine within 5 minutes: 65% response; after 30 min: much lower
IM midazolam works as well as IV lorazepam if no IV access (RAMPART trial)
ESETT trial: Fosphenytoin = Levetiracetam = Valproate for second-line
Subtle SE: only eye deviation or nystagmus - EEG needed for diagnosis
Super-refractory SE may require ketamine, immunotherapy, or ketogenic diet
common_misconceptions: All convulsive activity is convulsive SE - may be PNES or movement disorder
Benzodiazepines always work if given enough - efficacy decreases with time
Seizure stops = patient is safe - need EEG to rule out non-convulsive SE

citations.authors: Kapur J, Elm J, Chamberlain JM, et al.
citations.title: ESETT Investigators. Randomized Trial of Three Anticonvulsant Medications for Status Epilepticus

evidence.confidence_rationale: Based on ESETT trial and established treatment guidelines

sources.source: AAN Guideline: Status Epilepticus in Adults. Neurology. 2016.
Adams and Victor's Principles of Neurology, 11th ed. McGraw-Hill, 2019.
